channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Fossilised footprints discovered in Tanzania suggest women foraged together
item.description: The find is the largest collection of footprints from the human fossil record ever found in Africa, according to the team from Chatham University.

item.title: Ministers 'were warned of sustained coronavirus transmission' in February
item.description: The SPI-M released a statement on February 10 which stated that there was a 'realistic probability' that there is already a 'sustained transmission in the UK'.

item.title: NHS tracing app advisors 'cannot decide if they should consider telling ministers to ditch strategy'
item.description: The ethical advisory board debated how big a role it should play in discussing whether the app, currently being trialled in the Isle of Wight, is the best version, during a meeting on Thursday.

item.title: Boris declares war on fat: PM ditches his 'nanny state' worries and demands action
item.description: Mr Johnson is convinced he had such a tough battle with Covid-19 in part due to being significantly overweight. He's told senior advisers that it left him determined to lead a public health drive.

item.title: London records just 24 new covid-19 cases a day raising hopes lockdown could be eased
item.description: Analysis by Public Health England and Cambridge University calculated that the 'R' reproduction rate has fallen to 0.4 in the capital, and could see cases eradicated within a fortnight.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor saves life of pneumonia-stricken heart surgeon
item.description: Dr Shakil Rahman, the lead respiratory consultant at Epsom and St Helier NHS Trust, has spoken of his joy after he was able to treat his former heart surgeon Venkatachalam Chandrasekaran.

item.title: BBC comes under pressure to sack Radio 5 Live presenter Sam Quek for breaching advertising rules
item.description: Sam Quek, 31, who hosts 606, Radio 5 Live's football phone-in, was warned that she was breaking advertising rules but she continued promoting Footie5 on Twitter to her 175,000 followers.

item.title: Facebook appoints 'privacy committee' on its board
item.description: Independent directors Peggy Alford and Robert Kimmitt will serve as members of Facebook's new privacy committee under chair Nancy Killefer, who joined the board in March.

item.title: Coronavirus: TALKING in confined spaces can cause spread
item.description: National Institutes of Health researchers found that droplets of coronavirus-containing spit emitted when people talk can linger in the air for between eight and 12 minutes, infecting others.

item.title: He was a pillar of a rural community but 'Thomas Fairfax' was actually a murderer
item.description: No one could have appeared more plausible than Thomas Fairfax, the middle-aged divorcee who arrived in the small Gloucestershire town of Lydney in the winter of 1991.

item.title: BAZ BAMIGBOYE: Drag wasn't my bag but I love it! Richard E. Grant talks
item.description: BAZ BAMBIGBOYE: Richard E. Grant is ready for his closeup...as a drag queen. The Oscar-nominated actor has undergone a head-to-toe transformation.

item.title: Study finds just 1% of coronavirus patients who received plasma suffered side effects
item.description: A new study, led by the Mayo Clinic, found that among 5,000 critically and severely ill coronavirus patients who were treated with convalescent plasma, just 1% suffered serious side effects.

item.title: Britons across the country step outside their homes in eighth weekly 'Clap for Carers' event
item.description: The Prime Minister Boris Johnson's fiancée Carrie Symonds joined the millions across the country to pay tribute to the thousands of NHS staff and healthcare workers.

item.title: Skincare experts reveal five home beauty hacks that will bulk your bank balance
item.description: Australians can save big money on cosmetics by switching designer products for basic household items, likely to be sitting in the bathroom cabinet or kitchen cupboard already.

item.title: One million self-employed sign up to government furlough scheme in two days, treasury figures show
item.description: As many as 440,000 flooded the portal when it opened on Wednesday, and a further 500,000 applied yesterday. The treasury expects a further torrent of applications today.

item.title: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: Opera star Luciano Pavarotti's 'niece' preys on high society
item.description: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: Pavarotti, who died in 2007, left £380 million and four daughters by two wives - but no niece

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... the back-to-school row
item.description: PAUL THOMAS on... the back-to-school row

item.title: The eight-hour airport check: How Hong Kong is screening all arrivals to keep a lid on coronavirus
item.description: Photographer Laurel Chor, 30, recorded her arrival yesterday, starting with her being given a tracking bracelet in case she broke the mandatory 14-day quarantine.

item.title: Two people are 'arrested over the Costa del Sol shooting of a businessman from Manchester'
item.description: Peter Andrew Williamson, 39, from Salford, Greater Manchester, was killed as he parked outside his luxury villa in Riviera del Sol near Fuengirola last November.

item.title: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: Bond girl Britt wants a husband - and any husband will do...
item.description: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: Ex-Bond girl Britt Ekland just wants a husband, and any husband will do.

item.title: Man is found stabbed to death in an alleyway in Dartford as police arrest man in his 40s
item.description: Officers were called to the scene in Dartford, Kent, after a man in his 40s was found deceased in an alley near Oakfield Lane.

item.title: Gardener befriends robin during coronavirus lockdown
item.description: Keen gardener Kate MacRae from Lichfield was stunned when a robin - now named Colin - she had been feeding in her garden took their friendship to a whole new level.

item.title: China's ambassador to Britain DENIES Covid cover-up and says now isn't the time for WHO probe
item.description: Liu Xiaoming last night claimed that the Communist government has no problem with a probe of its wet markets and laboratories to see if Covid-19 originated in Wuhan.

item.title: Europe could be hit by a double wave of Covid-19 in the autumn, WHO warns
item.description: Dr Hans Kluge, director of the WHO in Europe, warned, in spite of countries were easing their lockdowns amid falling rates of coronavirus, it was time to prepare for a second wave.

item.title: Online searches for raunchy novels such as Fifty Shades of Grey surge
item.description: Online searches have bloomed the most in Norfolk and the East of England, while Londoners were found to be the least interested. Searches for cinemas, restaurants and flights dropped three-fold.

item.title: Prince William supports Christchurch mosque members affected by the 2019 mass shooting
item.description: Prince William, 37, has supported Christchurch mosque members affected by the March 2019 mass shooting. The royal reconnected with the survivors over a video call on Thursday.

item.title: Steven Spielberg's epic new project cost $2billion... for mini-movies that only last ten minutes
item.description: Quibi unleashes a whole new way of telling stories - delivering shows, lasting ten minutes or less, to smartphones. Steven Spielberg has signed up with the streaming service to make a horror series.

item.title: City centre parking charges could be AXED in a bid to tempt commuters off buses and trains
item.description: Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said parking charges may be waived to ward commuters off trains. His announcement comes after London Mayor Sadiq Khan threatened even fewer buses and trains.

item.title: Unlucky woman in Rio de Janeiro dodges flying vehicle tyre only for it to hit her in the head
item.description: An unnamed woman was smacked to the floor face first when she narrowly avoided a flying tyre in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, but it ricocheted off a bus shelter and hit her in the back of the head.

item.title: Panorama's PPE probe sparks almost 800 complaints of Labour bias
item.description: The programme, titled Has The Government Failed The NHS?, made a series of damaging claims about the Government's handling of the Covid-19 crisis.

item.title: Couple who reported man and woman tell of their horror after police found human TORSO in suitcase
item.description: Gemma and David Greenway, who live in Coleford, Gloucestershire, said they were 'shaken' by the horrific find, after reporting a man acting suspiciously behind their former sawmill.

item.title: Mary-Kate Olsen DENIED emergency divorce amid COVID-19 court closures
item.description: The former Full House star, who's 33, had claimed her 50-year-old husband is kicking her out of the apartment they share in the city, giving her only until Monday to find a new home amid the lockdown.

item.title: Tank of petrol £20 MORE at motorway services than supermarkets
item.description: With Morrisons, Asda and Tesco all lowering the price of unleaded below £1-a-litre this week, the gulf between fuel prices at motorway services and supermarkets has widened to over 36p per litre.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: 'Extraordinary' doctor, still working at 84, dies
item.description: Dr Karamat Mirza, who was raised in Pakistan by a family of doctors before moving to England, was still treating patients up until two weeks ago at the Old Road Medical Practice at Clacton-on-Sea.

item.title: Top Gear will resume production NEXT MONTH using 'strictly limited' crews and social distancing
item.description: Top Gear is set to resume filming in June.

item.title: Japan's suicide rate falls by a fifth during coronavirus pandemic
item.description: According to the country's Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare, the number of suicides this April was down by nearly 20 per cent compared to the same month in 2019.

item.title: Teachers' union threatens to SUE school chiefs if staff are put at risk
item.description: NASUWT, which has 310,000 members, has claimed it has put the government 'on notice' over plans to reopen schools. Its national official for education has warned against June 1 reopening.

item.title: Now the sun has gone into lockdown!
item.description: Big news this week about the giant, burning, boiling, spinning thermonuclear reactor which lies 93 million miles away from Earth but is our primary source of life-­giving heat and light.

item.title: Phone of missing girl, 16, was switched off in skate park near her Hampshire home
item.description: Teenager Louise Smith has not been seen or heard from since she disappeared from Havant, Hampshire, on May 8. Detectives have made a plea for her to contact them or her relatives.
item.media:credit: HNP Picture Desk/Hyde News & Pictures Ltd

item.title: Coronavirus US: Tablet vaccine is about to go into human trials
item.description: Immunologist Dr. Sean Tucker is currently trialing several different COVID-19 vaccine candidates at his San Francisco lab, believing there will be a vaccine out by next year.

item.title: Princess Maria Galitzin, 31, suddenly dies leaving behind a two-year-old son
item.description: Descendant of Emperor Karl of Austria Princess Maria Galitzine, 31, suffered a cardiac aneurysm and died, leaving behind her husband Rishi Singh and two-year-old son Maxim.

item.title: Five million antibody kits are on standby for the NHS after a SECOND test was approved by officials
item.description: The new test produced by Abbott has been approved by Public Health England after one produced by Roche Diagnostics was ratified two days ago. The Department of Health is in talks with both firms.

item.title: TOM UTLEY: Let's give thanks to gardeners like Mrs U
item.description: TOM UTLEY: Over the past 53 days, many of us will have caught ourselves wishing we were locked down with a hairdresser, or perhaps an IT specialist.

item.title: New wearable device is launched to alert employees if they stray too close to colleagues
item.description: Tharsus has designed the Bump devices specifically for the coronavirus outbreak, so staff can keep aware of their location in the workplace in relation to others, helping to maintain two-metre distancing.

item.title: Time to get back to class: Row between teachers and unions explodes...
item.description: The confrontation between teachers and unions exploded last night as the former Labour education secretary, David Blunkett, intervened to warn disadvantaged pupils were being penalised.

item.title: Bird of prey persecution crimewave during coronavirus lockdown
item.description: RSPB's dedicated Investigations Unit says it has been inundated with reports of predatory birds being illegally killed in Britain in recent weeks.

item.title: Death of a 747: Iconic Boeing jet is dismantled for scrap
item.description: The scrapped Boeing 747 was photographed being dismantled in St Athan, Wales, after being decommissioned last year.

item.title: Studies provide more evidence that coronavirus damages the kidneys
item.description: Two new studies, from Germany and New York, have found high levels of the coronavirus virus in the kidneys and kidney damage in more than one-third of hospitalized COVID-19 patients.

item.title: Now police warn you NOT to step in road to dodge fellow pedestrians
item.description: Police have warned pedestrians not to try and social distance on pavements if it means walking into the road. They say briefly crossing paths with someone 'won't give you Covid-19'.

item.title: Writer Olivia Fane has a stark warning for anyone tempted by an open marriage
item.description: I followed during the 'rules' of our open marriage for the eight years I was with my husband, the writer Adam Nicolson. Those rules ultimately led to our very painful divorce eight years later.

item.title: Kate Garraway claps for carers amid husband Derek's battle against coronavirus
item.description: The GMB presenter watched her neighbours light coloured smoke flares in the 8pm Clap for Carers on Thursday night, as her husband Derek Draper continues his battle against coronavirus.

item.title: Couple with 30-year age gap tied the knot in the nude
item.description: Nigel Seymour, 59, and wife Rachel, 30, from Poole, Dorset, met playing table tennis 'au naturel' on a Greek island holiday in June 2017. They tied the knot in 2019 surrounded by 40 wedding guests.

item.title: Hot off the press! How the Mail Force PPE was made in Britain
item.description: It is just a fortnight since the advent of Mail Force, the charity created with one simple, urgent aim: Securing PPE to protect those working in our hospitals and care sectors.

item.title: ANDREW PIERCE: The Corbynite lover of communist Cuba
item.description: ANDREW PIERCE: A clue as to the political philosophy of Dr Mary Bousted, the teachers' union leader trying to sabotage return to school, can be found in her passion for Cuba.

item.title: Body of newborn baby girl is discovered at Suffolk recycling plant sparking police probe
item.description: Suffolk Police discovered the lifeless body of a newborn baby girl at a recycling centre in Needham Market to the north of Ipswich at around 3pm today.

item.title: Andrew Lloyd Webber urges Government to copy South Korea's trace-and-test method to reopen theatres
item.description: Andrew Lloyd Webber has urged the Government to follow the example of South Korea to save the performing arts, a leaked letter to the Daily Mail shows.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: 220k in England may be infected currently
item.description: The first round of random public testing in England, carried out by the Office for National Statistics, detected just 33 positive COVID-19 cases out of a sample of 10,705 people - 0.27 per cent.

item.title: Donald Trump goes to another mask factory and does not wear a mask again
item.description: President Donald Trump did not wear a mask during a visit to a medical supply factory in Pennsylvania, marking the second time he wasn't pictured with a facial covering.

item.title: 'Elvis worms' found covered in iridescent scales that resemble the King of Rock's sequined suits
item.description: Scientists found four new members of deep-sea worms in the Gulf of California. Nicknamed 'Elvis worms', the critters have shiny, iridescent scales that look like the King's sequined suits.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Woman found dead on M4 after missing funeral
item.description: Abigail Hussey was found in the early hours of the morning after losing her 93-year-old grandmother to Covid-19 and being too worried to travel from South Wales to south-east England to say goodbye.

item.title: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN: Pay cuts? Clearly we are NOT all in this together
item.description: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN: With depressing predictability, it's politics as usual again. The temporary 'we're all in this together' truce didn't last long.

item.title: JAN MOIR: What kind of lowlife would spit at a woman like this?
item.description: JAN MOIR: So many deaths, so many stories of loss and worry, so many fears about the future. Yet few things about the pandemic have troubled me more than the death of Belly Mujinga.

item.title: Man who spat on Belly Mujinga was smartly dressed and 'looked like a lawyer', witness reveals
item.description: Belly Mujinga, 47, and a female colleague were coughed at and spat on by the suspect - who claimed to have Covid-19 - while they were on duty on March 22 at Victoria Station in London.

item.title: Queen Mathilde of Belgium and daughter Princess Eléonore don protective masks and rubber gloves
item.description: Queen Mathilde of Belgium, 46, and Princess Eléonore, 12, donned protective masks and rubber gloves as they visited a community restaurant for homeless people today.

item.title: Desperate travel companies slash cost of winter sun getaways by hundreds of pounds
item.description: Tui has dropped the cost of one ten-night break in the Maldives starting on November 29 by £800. TravelSupermarket said 'you can get the equivalent of an extra star for your money' this winter.

item.title: Kate Middleton reveals her favourite entries to her community photography project so far
item.description: Kate Middleton has selected some of her favourite images that she has received so far as part of her community photography project, Hold Still, which captures life across the UK.

item.title: Interactive map allows you to compare the size of your garden
item.description: Londoners have the least access to their own private space although the figures show that black people in England are almost four times as likely as white people to live in properties without a garden.

item.title: Mask maker told whistleblower 'we're in deep s***'
item.description: Dr. Rick Bright, the HHS whistleblower, slammed the government's coronavirus response complaining 'we don't have a strategy or plan.'

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Antibody test could be rolled out in 'days'
item.description: Frontline workers, including those in the NHS, will be the first to get a new antibody test for Covid-19, England's deputy chief medical officer Professor Jonathan Van-Tam said today.

item.title: Vietnam battles to prevent critically ill British pilot becoming its first coronavirus death
item.description: The 43-year-old Briton, known only as 'Patient 91', has been on life support for 30 days in Vietnam and has just 10 per cent lung function left as doctors try to stop him becoming the country's first fatality.

item.title: Donald Trump claims he DID have a pandemic plan and makes his press secretary brandish it
item.description: President Donald Trump claimed he did have a playbook to battle the coronavirus as a whistleblower testifed on Capitol Hill on a lack of 'standard, centralized, coordinated plan.'

item.title: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle in video call with mental health workers
item.description: Prince Harry, 35, and Meghan Markle, 38, surprised Crisis Text Line staff on Thursday by joining in on their Zoom conference meeting.

item.title: Sir Mark Sedwill had coronavirus at same time as Boris Johnson
item.description: Downing Street today revealed for the first time that Cabinet Secretary Sir Mark Sedwill had coronavirus at approximately the same time as Boris Johnson.

item.title: Researchers capture musical pulses coming from distant Delta Scuti stars
item.description: Scientists have recorded new musical pulses from a mysterious type of star called Delta Scuti, which burn around twice as bright and twice as hot as the Earth's sun and appear to harmonize.

item.title: Mohammed Hadid building mansion next door to Meghan and Harry
item.description: The father of supermodels Bella and Gigi Hadid is building a giant mega-mansion next door to Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's Beverly Hills hideout, DailyMailTV can reveal.

item.title: Coronavirus US: Drug for rare bone marrow cancer tested
item.description: Researchers say selinexor, which is currently approved treat multiple myeloma, blocks a protein that allows coronavirus to multiply in our cells and plays a role in the inflammatory response.

item.title: Donald Trump 'will be banished from 'club' of former Presidents'
item.description: President Trump burned his bridges after trashing his predecessors and failing to show them respect - all 'cardinal sins' in the exclusive club of former leaders.

item.title: Sadiq Khan warned he WILL have to increase London travel fares to pay for £2bn coronavirus bailout
item.description: Ministers have agreed to hand Sadiq Khan a £1.1billion bail-out package with 'strings attached' to get London's transport system back up and running.

item.title: Kawasaki-like disease affecting children IS caused by the coronavirus
item.description: Exclusive: University of Birmingham researchers have found the Kawasaki-like disease occurs several weeks, or even months, after initial infection with SARS-CoV-2.

item.title: Grant Shapps pledges £2bn to improve road and rail networks
item.description: The Transport Secretary said Britain 'must exploit our new-found capacity to respond at pace' to major challenges and 'apply it to rapidly improving our infrastructure'.

item.title: Coronavirus Russia: Medics get £8 bonus for risking their lives
item.description: President Vladimir Putin had promised doctors a monthly bonus of up to £900 for treating virus patients. Many posted photos online of pay cheques where the extra money amounted to £8.

item.title: Coronavirus is FIVE TIMES deadlier than the seasonal flu, report finds
item.description: A new study from Harvard University found that the death rate on the Diamond Princess ship was 0.5% compared to 0.1% for the seasonal flu, which makes coronavirus five times deadlier.

item.title: Photographer creates Hobbit-style village with wooden houses for wild mice who visit his garden
item.description: Simon Dell, 46, from Sheffield created the houses resembling Lord of the Rings. The wildlife photographer befriended a mouse called George who has enjoyed exploring the setting in a photo series.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Student found dead in park had lockdown fears
item.description: Following 17-year-old Matthew Mackell's death in Dunorlan Park, Tunbridge Wells, Kent, his family says a notebook the A-level student had revealed fears for how lockdown would affect his exams.

item.title: Why there's an 'odd pocket' in the crotch of your knickers
item.description: Members of the British parenting site Mumsnet have been debating why there's a strange 'gussett feature' that 'leaves an odd pocket', and a Californian lifestyle blogger was able to provide the answer.

item.title: Takeaway fans queue for miles as favourite stores reopen after coronavirus lockdown
item.description: Huge queues of cars were spotted queuing at drive-thrus Inverness, Gateshead and Glasgow as coffee and fast food giants reopened UK branches amid an easing of lockdown measures.

item.title: Daughter of Happy Face serial killer recalls him strangling a cat
item.description: Crime correspondent Melissa Moore reflected on her childhood with her father Keith Hunter Jesperson during her appearance on Vice Australia's podcast Extremes.

item.title: PIERS MORGAN: Dithering, buck-passing Mayor Sadiq Khan is an absolute disgrace
item.description: On March 3, the Mayor of our largest and most densely populated city exuded supreme confidence that there was nothing to worry about, writes PIERS MORGAN.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: A quarter of patients who died had diabetes
item.description: Of the 22,332 patients who died since March 31, when pre-existing conditions began to be reported by NHS England, some 5,873 (26 per cent) of patients had diabetes.

item.title: IOC president Thomas Bach reveals decision to delay Tokyo Games until 2021 could cost £650MILLION
item.description: Thomas Bach said the IOC's executive committees has approved the sum to cover the costs of reorganisation and to support individual sports federations and national Olympic committees.

item.title: Suicides in England and Wales rise by 'deeply concerning' 11 per cent with 4,620 deaths in 2019
item.description: Men accounted for three times the number of suicides than women, data published today by the Ministry of Justice shows. Death by misadventure or accident was the most common verdict. (stock)

item.title: Coronavirus: Mouthwash could prevent transmission, report says
item.description: Mouthwash has potential to kill the coronavirus and prevent COVID-19 infection, according to a new report from virologists, lipid specialists and healthcare experts.

item.title: Angry Mercedes driver demands paramedics move ambulance
item.description: The man mouths off at the medics as they respond to an emergency in Earl's Court, west London. The driver stomps over to the paramedics and confronts them as they help a woman into the vehicle.

item.title: Doorbell films Hermes courier call disabled woman 'dozy b****'
item.description: David Gregson, 74, said the courier had been sent by Hermes to collect a parcel from his Blackpool home when he swore while talking to David's 74-year-old wife Kath.

item.title: Eight million patients will be on routine surgery NHS waiting lists by autumn due to coronavirus
item.description: Chief of the Nuffield Trust said hospitals in England have only been able to carry out around '15 to 20 per cent' of elective procedures, meaning up to 1.3million patients are missing out every month.

item.title: Mum 'overwhelmed' with spaghetti loops after urgent plea for tins to feed son with Down's Syndrome
item.description: Lisa Calder is mum to 15-year-old Duncan who has Down's syndrome and a sensory processing disorder. He has a limited diet which means he will only eat the Asda brand of his favourite snack.

item.title: Sabine Getty stays in bed til 3.30pm in coronavirus quarantine
item.description: Writing in Tatler, Sabine Getty, 36, said she's 'restless, exhausted, useless and depressed by the flow of bad news', while isolating 18th centurt Wormsley Park, in Buckinghamshire.

item.title: Former Daily Mail photographer Clive Limpkin dies aged 82
item.description: Photographer Clive Limpkin, who worked for the Daily Mail for 20 years, died on Wednesday at the age of 82 after being diagnosed with a brain tumour earlier this year.

item.title: Why you should MILK your cucumbers before eating them
item.description: The technique doesn't appear to be widely-known, even among frequent veggie eaters - but one TIkTok user is helping to spread the word.

item.title: 20 Colombian men who paid $2.50 to attend sex party arrested
item.description: Police in Cali, Colombian, busted into a private home Tuesday and apprehended 20 men who paid to attend a orgy party that featured prostitutes, drugs and liquor for a cover charge of $2.50.

item.title: Police worker wins farmhouse worth £650k with £2 raffle ticket
item.description: Alison Bellamy, from Shropshire, scooped a stunning new dream home after her ticket was pulled out of a hat on Thursday afternoon and said her children had 'already picked their rooms'.

item.title: Older people in happy marriages are more likely to go out and exercise
item.description: Researchers from the University of Hawaii studied public health data from Albania, Colombia and Brazil involving 1,193 adults aged 65-74.

item.title: Niall Horan blasts 'smug and slippery' Matt Hancock
item.description: The Irish singer, 26, hit out at Mr Hancock over the Government's handling of the coronavirus crisis amid calls for the Health Secretary to be sacked due to the slow start to Britain's testing regime.

item.title: Archaeologists unearth largest ever Pictish site...
item.description: Scientists date the settlement at Tap O´ Noth in Aberdeenshire to between the fifth and sixth centuries.
item.media:description: The hill settlement is perched high up the Tap O´ Noth (University of Aberdeen/PA)

item.title: French serial-killer expert admits most of life and work is FAKE
item.description: Stéphane Bourgoin, 67, wrote around 40 crime books and claimed he interviewed more than 70 serial killers. But he has admitted his 'murdered wife' never existed and much of his work is fake.

item.title: 'Horrible experience but we're ok now': Dele Alli speaks out after knifepoint robbery at £2m mansion
item.description: Premier League footballer Dele Alli and his girlfriend have been pictured for the first time since armed robbers burst into his North London home, held him at knife point and punched him in the face.

item.title: Police arrest man, 26, and woman, 24, on suspicion of murder after death of one-month old baby boy
item.description: Newborn Colby Lawton died in Newbury, Berkshire after being in cardiac arrest. A post-mortem has not yet determined how he died while the man and woman arrested over the death remain in custody.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Death toll hits 33,614 with 428 new fatalities
item.description: The UK has announced a further 428 deaths from coronavirus , taking Britain's total to 33,614. It includes 379 in England, 34 in Scotland, 10 in Wales and five in Northern Ireland.

item.title: Neighbours on 'millionaires' playground' estate locked in privacy row
item.description: This graphic shows the boundary between the properties owned by Robin Fraser, outlined in red, and Patrick Riley, outlined in blue. Mr Fraser claims the development will overlook his tennis court.

item.title: Care worker, 53, is found dead at home amid fears she had Covid-19
item.description: Jeanette McKenna (pictured right) had worked at Whitecraigs care home, in Thornliebank, Barrhead, for ten years. She was found dead at home on May 7.

item.title: British man jailed for 25 years in Croatia for stabbing compatriot to death outside a nightclub
item.description: Douglas Cane, 27, was found guilty of murdering fellow Briton Ugo Wilson and attempting to kill two other compatriots during a brawl, said the court in the coastal town of Zadar.

item.title: Chinese panda base tests all of its 208 bears for coronavirus
item.description: The Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding, which has 208 pandas, arranged the mass testing after some zoo animals in the United States had caught the bug, a spokesperson said.

item.title: Scaffolder spends three days and £170 building incredible back garden fortress for his two children
item.description: Marc Ely used the lockdown to transform his garden at his home in Rochford, Essex. The project was such a success, he is now looking to build similar structures for his customers.

item.title: Jonathan Creek actor Alan Davies tries to solve his own mystery by posting photos of burglars
item.description: The 54-year-old posted two photos of burglars, one of whom stole 'stuff' from his house whilst he was at the cinema pre-lockdown, but the second burglar was foiled 'the other day'.

item.title: One in 10 gamers suffer from 'pathological' video game addiction
item.description: Video game addiction is real in one out of every 10 gamers, according to a new study, and can result in mental, social and behavioural issues.

item.title: Liverpool mayor vows to 'resist' Government plans to reopen schools in June
item.description: Joe Anderson said that he would 'resist' efforts by ministers to allow primary school pupils to return by June 1, because of the high level of coronavirus cases remaining within the city.

item.title: Grieving father, 49, of three-day-old baby who died after mother tested positive for coronavirus
item.description: Speaking today from the couple's cottage in Maesteg, Carl Morgan, 49, told MailOnline he had a fleeting glimpse of his seriously-ill baby before he was put in an ambulance.

item.title: NASA claims initial motion is key to ensuring a real-life WARP ENGINE is in drive not reverse
item.description: NASA physicist Harold 'Sonny' White - who specialises in advanced propulsion technology - found that the leading warp drive theory had one major flaw.

item.title: Man in China shocked to find out ONE of newborn twins isn't his
item.description: The parent, who remains unidentified, made the shocking discovery after taking the newborns to undergo a DNA test as part of the standard procedure to register their births in China.
item.media:credit: Visual China Group via Getty Ima

item.title: Brain stimulation enables blind patients to 'see' the alphabet
item.description: Scientists have used electrode implants in the brain to allow blind people to see again. The system bypasses damaged eyes and delivers visual information directly to the visual cortex.

item.title: UFC light-heavyweight Glover Teixeira APOLOGISES mid-fight with Anthony Smith
item.description: UFC fighters are usually filled with animosity and aggression in the octagon but things took a bizarre, polite turn on Wednesday night.

item.title: Holiday Guru investigates claiming refunds for Airbnb bookings and BA flights and quarantine rules
item.description: If you need advice, the Holiday Guru is here to answer your questions. This week refunds and quarantine rules are the hot topics.

item.title: Coughing Amazon driver clears his throat and SPITS on customer's doorstep as he delivers a package
item.description: Michael Snasdell shared the doorbell footage from Forest Hill, Lewisham, on Twitter. The driver clears his throat as he takes the face mask away from his face and spits on the customer's doorstep.

item.title: Westminster Abbey worker inspects roof of 750-year-old church as historic London landmark is closed
item.description: Ian Bartlett was photographed checking the Triforium and Henry VII roofs at the central London building despite it being closed to the public.

item.title: Flight attendant accused of performing sex act during Virgin flight wins £10k for wrongful dismissal
item.description: Virgin Australia New Zealand (VANZ) Staff member Seaooloumalo Loli was accused following a flight in February 2018.

item.title: Labour fury at Nadine Dorries over 'fake news' Twitter video slamming Keir Starmer on grooming gangs
item.description: Health minister Ms Dorries shared an interview with the opposition leader heavily edited to suggest he had been reluctant to prosecute grooming gangs when director of public prosecutions.

item.title: Government borrowing is set to soar to nearly £300BILLION this year, OBR warns
item.description: The OBR's latest 'scenario' for the crisis says the economy will shrink 35 per cent in this quarter - more than predicted by the Bank of England but unchanged from its previous numbers last month.

item.title: Keep the vine fires burning!
item.description: As temperatures dropped to almost freezing across the Albury Vineyard last night, more than 800 candles were lit among the budding fruit in an effort to prevent frosts from destroying the harvest.

item.title: Kitty Spencer shares a sweet throwback of her siblings and admits she 'misses them'
item.description: Lady Kitty Spencer, 29, shared a sweet black and white throwback picture of her as a child with siblings Lady Amelia and her twin Lady Eliza Spencer, now 27, and Louis Spencer, now 26.

item.title: Council workers spray Hull clean with 7,000 litres of water
item.description: The clean-up operation, designed to help suppress the coronavirus, is to be spread across Hull with all main arterial roads, cycle routes and 52 shopping developments to have a similar deep clean.

item.title: Jamie Oliver submits plans for home improvements at his £6million mansion despite furloughing staff
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: The 44-year-old chef (pictured with his wife Jools) lodged applications to fix an oak double-door onto the front of his Grade I-listed Essex country pad to Braintree District Council on April 23.

item.title: How accurate is Roche's newly-approved antibody test?
item.description: MailOnline reveals everything you need to know about Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche's antibody test, from how accurate it is to how it will be used in the UK.

item.title: David Beckham sports a fuller 'do as he embarks on a run near his Cotswolds home
item.description: The former footballer, 45, has appeared to grow out his buzz cut as he embarked on a run near his Cotswolds home on Thursday, just days after sporting thinner locks.

item.title: High court rejects claim badger cull ban due to Carrie Symonds
item.description: The National Farmers' Union told Mrs Justice Andrews that lobbying by Badger Trust chief Dominic Dyer included meeting Mr Johnson's partner, Ms Symonds, in Downing Street.

item.title: Trade bodies call for six-month MOT exemption to be AXED over road safety fears
item.description: Major automotive bodies including the SMMT, IGA and IMI have warned that many of the cars being used again from this week due to eased lockdown rules will not be in safe condition.

item.title: German cafe makes customers wear swimming noodle hats to enforce social distancing
item.description: Customers sitting outside Cafe & Konditorei Rothe in Schwerin, Germany, all wore straw hats with two swimming pool noddles taped to the top to make sure they didn't flout social distancing rules.

item.title: British Airways plane carrying 328 passengers collided with refuelling vehicle at Heathrow T3
item.description: The collision took place in heavy rain as the Boeing 747 approached its final parking space at Heathrow Airport Terminal 3 in December. The driver was in the fuel transfer vehicle at the time but was unhurt.

item.title: Swapping CFCs for other chemicals may have led to contaminated food
item.description: York University researchers examined the long-term impact of the 1987 Montreal Protocol designed to limit the use chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

item.title: Gucci mocked for a £675 bag from 2018 made of rubber that looks like £4 a laundry bag from B&M
item.description: Italian luxury brand Gucci is being mocked online after one of its designs from 2018 resurfaced. Unimpressed fans of the brand compared the rubber bag to a wash bin and a plasterer's bucket.

item.title: Out with a bang: German nuclear power station's cooling towers demolished in spectacular explosion
item.description: The demolition, at the site of the Philippsburg power plant, near Karlsruhe, south-western Germany, took place just after 6am on Thursday.

item.title: Plans to build homes on 'irreplaceable' nature reserve fail after David Attenborough joined campaign
item.description: Sir David Attenborough had called on 'all those who love the natural world' to back a campaign to halt the plans for homes near Askham Bog in North Yorkshire.

item.title: Another 14 migrants reach Dover, as Home Office chiefs confirm fortnight quarantine for arrivals
item.description: MailOnline can exclusively reveal today that asylum seekers and illegal migrants will face an automatic two week quarantine on entering the UK.

item.title: Body found washed up on beach is missing estate agent
item.description: Norfolk Police revealed today that the body found on Monday evening at Sizewell, Suffolk, had been identified as 23-year-old Chelsie Dack of Gorleston-on-Sea, Norfolk.
item.media:description: Chelsie Dack was reported missing on April 20 (Norfolk Police/PA)

item.title: People share the most entitled messages they've received
item.description: Bored Panda has collated infuriating exchanges from across the globe, revealing outrageous requests by extremely entitled people, including one who asked an entertained to perform for free.

item.title: Rochdale grooming gang victim bumped into freed abuser
item.description: The woman, who cannot be identified, said she ran from the supermarket in Rochdale town centre in tears and reported Adil Khan, 50, to authorities as he was with a young child.

item.title: Bear who ransacked couples kitchen after breaking into their log cabin does 'no damage'
item.description: Michelle Eberhart, from Indiana, told This Morning how a bear broke into the cabin in Tennessee, where was staying with friends, but didn't do much damage other than leaving a chocolatey paw print.

item.title: Small number of people may develop PSYCHOSIS after contracting coronavirus
item.description: A team of Australian researchers claim a small number of COVID-19 patients may develop psychosis as a symptom of their infection.

item.title: Fresh air and sunshine are protective against the coronavirus
item.description: Professor Alan Penn, a member of SAGE, said: 'The science suggests that being outside in sunlight, with good ventilation, are both highly protective against transmission of the virus.'

item.title: A labyrinth of bollard-protected cycle lanes begins to crop up across London
item.description: Mayfair's prestigious Park Lane (pictured) is the latest road to be lined with shiny black and white bollards to allow bikers safe passage through busy city traffic.

item.title: Women brands catfish pathetic after her photos were stolen and used in viral covid-19 conspiracy
item.description: Sarah-Louise Cooper, from Manchester, told BuzzFeed , her photos were used by a now-deleted Facebook profile, of a made-up woman called Sara Faith.

item.title: Police warn mother of eight for taking children out after mistaking them for TWO families
item.description: Marie Buchan from Birmingham went to Lickey Hills in Worcestershire with five of her children for half an hour of exercise. The 37-year-old said an officer told them to go home.

item.title: Stunning photos of BOTH world wars and intervening conflicts are brought to life in colour
item.description: From the muddy fields of Passchendaele in 1917 to the beaches of Normandy in 1944, Brazilian artist Marina Amaral has added full colour digital renditions of 200 images.

item.title: Afghan mother breastfeeds TWENTY newborns at maternity ward where 'ISIS' gunmen slaughtered babies
item.description: Feroza Younis Omar volunteered to feed babies who lost their mothers in the attack on the Doctors Without Borders maternity unit in Kabul, which saw 24 people killed including two newborn babies.

item.title: Neil 'Razor' Ruddock threatens to beat up Paul Merson after furious row over drinking
item.description: The pair clashed in the latest series of 'Harry's Heroes' after Merson, who has suffered from alcohol addiction in the past, took exception to Ruddock downing pints and shots in the pub during filming.

item.title: Naga Munchetty confirms: 'All four main presenters of BBC Breakfast are paid equally'
item.description: BBC Breakfast presenter Naga Munchetty has spoken about some of the racism she encoutered while growing up.

item.title: City watchdog orders insurers to offer payment holidays from Monday
item.description: The Financial Conduct Authority today confirmed a series of temporary measures to help insurance customers who may be in financial difficulty because of coronavirus.

item.title: Armed police swooped on swordsman to discover man on his daily exercise in knight fancy dress
item.description: Police were left bemused when they discovered that the man was out on his daily exercise carrying a 3ft sword in his fancy dress medieval knight costume at Hendre Lake, in St Mellons, Cardiff.

item.title: Mortgage rates at lowest ever level but fail to keep pace with BoE cut
item.description: Individual deals have been cheaper in the past, despite the Bank of England slashing base rate to a record low of 0.1 per cent

item.title: Coronavirus: Japanese 'Black light' experiment shows how easily germs spread in restaurants
item.description: In the Japanese study, one person was 'infected' with fluorescent paint, mimicking a virus. Ten people then tucked into a buffet before a blue light turned on, showing how widely the 'virus' spread.

item.title: 12,000 British Airways job cuts to go ahead despite furlough extension
item.description: IAG chief executive Willie Walsh had told MPs on Monday, before the extension announcement by Chancellor Rishi Sunak, that he was not 'picking on' British Airways.

item.title: How the crucial coronavirus 'R' rate varies across England
item.description: It is the latest piece of evidence that northern towns are now bearing the brunt of the crisis. The real-time R tracking was conducted by researchers from Cambridge University and PHE.

item.title: T.rex was a champion WALKER and had long legs adapted to conserve energy while prowling for prey
item.description: Researchers from Mount Marty College, South Dakota used data on limb proportions, body mass and the gait of 70 species of therapod dinosaurs

item.title: Fishermen create mesmerising patterns as they trawl for anchovies in Vietnam
item.description: The beautiful images were taken in An Hai, Phu Yen Province, Vietnam, by photographer and banker Khanh Phan, 34.

item.title: Ex-pat Britons ignore Covid-19 social distancing to down drinks, swim and sing at UAE beach hotel
item.description: Dozens of British ex-pats have checked into the luxury resort in Ras Al Khaimah where pool parties are held each day and alcohol is readily available - even during Ramadan.

item.title: Buyers are demanding big discounts as housing market bursts back into life following lockdown
item.description: Estate agents reported a surge in demand yesterday after ministers lifted a seven-week ban on home moves. But experts warned of a 'Mexican standoff' as fears linger over a price crash.

item.title: Imposing lockdown sooner could have prevented 2,000 coronavirus deaths in Scotland, study finds
item.description: University of Edinburgh researchers said eight out of 10 coronavirus deaths in Scotland could have been prevented if the measures were brought in on March 9 instead of March 23 (shown).

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Death toll hits 32,490 with 425 new fatalities
item.description: Today's victims were announced as a report from the Office for National Statistics revealed the true number of people to have died in England and Wales alone was already at 35,044 by May 1.

item.title: UK's crucial coronavirus R rate could be JUST below one, Boris Johnson admits
item.description: The Prime Minister made clear in his address to the UK tonight that how the nation moves forward to emerge from lockdown will hinge entirely on the R rate of the virus and keeping it below 1.
